subject: log_services: Add download of log entries
commitMessage:
log_services: Add download of log entries

Add a GET function for endpoint
/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/attachment/<str>
which would read the File Path property of the specified entry,
encode it as base64, and send it off. This allows the user to
offload error logs for analysis and further parsing if needed.
An http header of "Accept: application/octet-stream" or the default "*/*"
is expected.

Tested:
- Ran Redfish validator.

- Verified the contents of the offloaded file were the same as
the file in the BMC, after decoding it with a base64 decoder.
curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" \
   https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/attachment/2

- Verified the supported Accept header values, ex:
"Accept: application/octet-stream;q=1"
"Accept: text/plain;q=0,application/octet-stream;q=1,multipart/form-data;q=2"

- Verified an unsupported Accept header returned "Bad Request", ex:
curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -H "Accept: application/*"
curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -H "Accept: foo, not/supported"

- Verified 404 was returned for a not found endpoint:
$ curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/attachment/foo
{
  "error": {
    "@Message.ExtendedInfo": [
      {
        "@odata.type": "#Message.v1_1_1.Message",
        "Message": "The requested resource of type EventLogAttachment named foo was not found.",
        "MessageArgs": [
          "EventLogAttachment",
          "foo"
        ],
        "MessageId": "Base.1.8.1.ResourceNotFound",
        "MessageSeverity": "Critical",
        "Resolution": "Provide a valid resource identifier and resubmit the request."
      }
    ],
    "code": "Base.1.8.1.ResourceNotFound",
    "message": "The requested resource of type EventLogAttachment named foo was not found."
  }
}

Change-Id: Id9e2308ebedc70852a2ed62def107648f7e6fb7a
Signed-off-by: Adriana Kobylak <anoo@us.ibm.com>

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 400fd1fb4020028ad58b1cfd965f26d21f63b8c8 by Ed Tanous

I still haven't seen a response to how this is going to work when privilege isolation works.  I suspect this file descriptor needs to come from dbus rather than reading and writing directly to the filesystem.

Done. Talking with Matt, created a new phosphor-logging interface to return the fd. Waiting on approval for commits:
pdi: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/40351
logging: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-logging/+/40361
std::string ?
Done. Sure.
This makes it look like you're trying to make this file downloadable in the browser.  That largely defeats the purpose of base64 encoding it.
Done. Agree, we're not sending an attachment file anymore, removed.
typo?
Done. thanks.
needs escaped for dbus.
Done. Learning all kinds of good stuff.

I don't see proper handling of 404s here.

/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/attachment/foobar should return 404.

FYI, I'm adding this to COMMON_ERRORS.md.  You're far from the first person to get this wrong.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/40429
Done. Thanks for explaining this.
How does it know it needs to close the fd?  Are you sure this is the case?  Is there a systemd/dbus doc on this that you have a link to handy? (asking earnestly, because I've never done this before).

I didn't find any documentation, but if a close is called, this error shows up saying systemd is trying to close an invalid fd:

bmcweb[256]: Assertion 'close_nointr(fd) != -EBADF' failed at src/basic/fd-util.c:72, function safe_close(). Aborting.

Then I found that Deepak ran into this same issue when calling the getPEL interface and concluded systemd was closing the fd (https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/1b4a98af49059da61695c41469e4b7b134c1bf68/org/open_power/Logging/PEL.interface.yaml#L4).

@Deepak, did you find any documentation when you saw this issue?
Done. Did more searching, we need to dup the fd, I verified the fd number doesn't increase with each call so we're correctly closing and re-using it.

Why do we need to dup the FD?  Did you find some docs somewhere that said that?

Btw, this is for my own learning, as I suspect this pattern is going to come up a lot more.

Yeah, there are already 2 pdi interfaces that return an fd. There was an example here on how to pass the fd through dbus: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40869161/how-do-i-send-a-unix-file-descriptor-using-sdbus

Adding the dup/close, prevented the fd number from increasing, so that seems to be reusing the fd instead of leaving it open.
why was the dup needed?
oh, it's so you can close it.  nevermind.
Done. Yep.
Should you check for -1 here?
Done
Done
More common in bmcweb to see int
#include ?
What if the file is 120GB?  We need some sanity checks here.

> #include ?
Added #include <unistd.h>

> What if the file is 120GB?  We need some sanity checks here.
Added check for 64kb file size. The phosphor-logging repo doesn't specify a file size limit, but the PEL extensions enforces a size of 16kb, and a PEL adds more data to the error log entry (https://github.ibm.com/openbmc/phosphor-logging/blob/master/extensions/openpower-pels/README.md#ffdc-intended-for-userdata-pel-sections)
Done. lseek and read return a long long int.
this can be a string view to avoid the data copy.
Done. Makes sense.

Should we verify that the user requested text/plain before sending it to them?  We don't on redfish generally, because the URI is enough to know that they expect json, but here.

Also, octet-stream seems like an better fit, so long as we don't have a content-disposition, it won't download as a file, right?

Yes, makes sense to change to octet-stream as that's the content type after being decoded.
I added a check for "Accept-Encoding" to be base64, that should make it obvious to the caller that they're to receive a text file encoded as base64.

But this isn't a text file, right?  This is binary?

You also need a check the accept header to make sure that they are ok receiving text files:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Accept
Done. Added check for "Accept: text/plain"

The property isn't missing, a header is missing.  This is a form of 400 bad request error.

Also, because this isn't a redfish API, I wonder if we should avoid sending redfish return codes.  Maybe just set 400 on the response?

Really need a headerMissing..
https://redfish.dmtf.org/registries/Base.1.9.0.json

I can open an issue with the DMTF as long you/Ed agree ?
Done. Removed check for missing Accept, the Accept header is always provided with a default value of */* if the caller does not specify it.
I think it makes sense to add a missing header, for now we'll be returning 400/bad-request

if you wanted to, you could.  This api isn't strictly "redfish" as we're not sending json, so I suspect we also shouldn't be obeying the return codes from redfish, otherwise we'd get requests that accept octet stream, but return json, which is funky.

This needs properly parsed.  boost has utility functions for parsing stuff like this that you should use.

technically text/plain;q=0.9 is also legal here.
Why text/plain if below application/octet-stream..
Done. Fixed, returning text/plain. I misunderstood/mixed previous review comments.
Done. Added parsing. We'll be checking for the default */* (all types accepted) and text/plain.
This isn't a property, so this value also should be a form of 400 bad request.

headerValueNotInList 
For the DMTF.. I think this is fine for now.
Sounds good.
Done

In my experience this isn't used that often. 
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Accept-Encoding

What happens on the default here ?
i.e. what happens if the client doesn't include?
*
    Matches any content encoding not already listed in the header. This is the default value if the header is not present. It doesn't mean that any algorithm is supported; merely that no preference is expressed.
Done. Removed. Only expecting the Accept header to support clients that don't specify any type and can handle any type.
Same as above.
Done. Removed encoding header.
Same as above.
Done. Removed encoding header.
nit: Can you put this on line 1714 just so this looks like all the other handlers?  That makes it easier when this api gets fixed.
Done. Makes sense.
I think you got some patches mismatched.  You check for accepting text/plain, then you return application/octet-stream.
Done. Yeah, I misunderstood/mixed the previous review comments.

https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_70_0/libs/beast/doc/html/beast/ref/boost__beast__http__param_list.html

Is the boost code I was referring to.  It parses this the way the RFC expects.

Done. As a workaround, we can still use the http iterators if we replace the '/' with some other character. Looking at the http/detail/rfc7230.ipp boost file, seems we can use |, ^, `, etc, so choosing | since the iterators offer the advantage that they split out the ';q=X' string for us so we can do an exact compare of the type. Using ext_list since that's a comma-separated string which is the format of the Accept header.

There's 4 different variants of the RFC7230 parser, ext_list, opt_token_list, param_list, and token_list.  I would expect one of them to have the correct behavior here, considering they're implemented for this use case.

I have not looked at the differences between them, but I'd be really surprised if they didn't have a way to parse out */*, assuming it's valid in the spec.

Yeah, weird that they don't handle the '/', seems their parsing is common. Didn't see anything in the issues page either, just a couple complains about param_list requiring the list to start with a semicolon since most fields don't start with that (https://github.com/boostorg/beast/issues/2096).

Seems the '/' would need to be added to the 'is_token_char' here: https://github.com/boostorg/beast/blob/50512cb5cd55e4e7dd51c13e5ff37a605a379e54/include/boost/beast/http/detail/rfc7230.ipp#L80

Otherwise, the parsers stop when they encounter a '/' because it's not a char, nor a delimiter like a comma or semicolon.
But in this context, the / isn't a token char, it's text.  I would expect it to pass the is_text check above the one you linked.....
Yeah, although doesn't seem the is_text is called anywhere in the code, maybe their parsing would need to be improved.
I submitted a PR to boost to handle the '/' character: https://github.com/boostorg/beast/pull/2209

Their suggestion was to create our own function:

"I thought I already implemented that, but if I didn't - yes, it would be nice to have. However, you cannot change detail::is_token_char because the HTTP parser uses that, and the RFC does not allow a slash for the places where is_token_char is called from the parser. You would need to make your own function, e.g. is_ext_token_char and use that instead."

Should I implement a custom parser in the bmcweb http header file?
both case insensitive, and contains seem wrong here.  I would expect exact matches on a properly parsed element.
Done. Yeah, using the boost iterators allows us to compare for an exact match now.
See below, I'm pretty sure this isn't human readable text.
Done. Yeah, changed to octet-stream since that's the original source format.
Also need to verify that size elements were read in.
Done. Agree.

At this level, this isn't text.  I would've expected octet-stream, and also to look for octet stream.

in your use case is this human readable text?
Done. It's not text, changed to octet-stream, eoncded as base64.
nit.  std::move() here to avoid the copy.
Done. Good point.
Does token_list require this cheat as well?
Yeah, token_list is the same, it just prints the first '*'. Seems all iterators use the same parsing and don't handle the '/'.
